metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of the automatic meteorological observations at the Linze inland river basin comprehensive research station (2008-2009)
metadata.description:
This data set includes the observation data of the automatic meteorological station from January 2008 to September 2009 in Linze Inland River Basin Comprehensive station. The station is located in Linze County, Zhangye City, Gansu Province, with longitude and latitude of 100 ° 08 ′ e, 39 ° 21 ′ N and altitude of 1382m. 
The observation items include: atmospheric temperature and humidity gradient observation (1.5m and 3.0m), wind speed (2.2m and 3.7m), wind direction, air pressure, precipitation, net radiation and total radiation, carbon dioxide (2.8m and 3.5m), soil tension, multi-layer soil temperature (20cm, 40cm, 60cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm) and soil heat flux (5cm, 10cm and 15cm). 
Please refer to the instruction document published with the data for specific header and other information.

background: The near-surface atmospheric elements including air temperature, pressure, relative humility, wind, precipitation and radiation are called forcing data to drive hydrological, land surface, and ecological models. Coupling or use of the General Circulation Model (GCM) output to drive the land surface model is an important source of forcing data for large-scale land surface models, however the spatial and temporal resolution can not meet the requirements of a regional scale land surface model and its coarse resolution ignored regional environmental impact assessment. Thus, a regional scale land surface model or land surface data assimilation system needs forcing data with a higher temporal-spatial resolution. Therefore, downscaling GCM output is necessary in order to prepare for a long series of high spatial and temporal resolution forcing data for regional scale or basin-scale land surface, hydrological and ecological simulation and assimilation. Downscaling is a method of obtaining high-resolution climate or climate change information from relatively coarse-resolution GCMs. Dynamic downscaling uses large scale climatic background information to establish higher resolution meteorological distribution fields by GCMs. Regional climate model is considered to be an effective dynamic downscaling method to derive high-resolution local climate information. The model’s physical meaning is clear, it is built on the nonlinear interaction between large scale and regional scale, and can distinguish local features characterized by local topography, vegetation cover and soil hydrological processes, and can be used anywhere independent of observation data with an improved description of local features.
research objective: In order to do the validation of WRF model on simulating forcing data for the Heihe River Basin, daily meteorological observation data from 15 stations of CMA (China Meteorological Administration) and hourly meteorological observation data from seven sites of WATER (Watershed Airborne Telemetry Experimental Research) are used to compare with WRF simulations, with a time range of a whole year for 2008. Thus, the validation accuracy of forcing data from RCM is important before input to drive the land surface model.
methods: The model was validated at 15 surface meteorological stations maintained by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and seven observation-strengthened stations setup by WATER project. In this study, WRF is used for downscaling of weather and climate ranging from one kilometer to thousands of kilometers and used for deriving meteorological parameters required for hydrological models. For this study, two way nested computational domains of 41×55×28 and 101×121×28 grid points and horizontal resolutions of 25 km and 5 km, respectively, have been set. The model is initialized by real boundary conditions using NCAR-NCEP’s Final Analysis (FNL) data (NCEP-DSS083.2, 2009) having a resolution of 1°×1° (111 km×111 km).
dataset: Daily meteorological observation data from 15 stations of CMA (China Meteorological Administration) and hourly meteorological observation data from seven sites of WATER (Watershed Airborne Telemetry Experimental Research) are used to compare with WRF simulations, with a time range of a whole year for 2008. The model was validated at 15 surface meteorological stations maintained by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and seven observation-strengthened stations setup by WATER project. Data from CMA stations are used for daily validation; the WATER’s are for hourly validation. All CMA data in 2008 are used for comparison, the time span of WATER’s are listed in Table 2.
findings: Results show that the average MBE (Mean Bias Error) of daily 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure, 2-m relative humidity and 10-m wind speed were −0.19 °C, −4.49 hPa, 4.08% and 0.92 m/s, the average RMSE (Root Mean Square Error) of them were 2.11 °C, 5.37 hPa, 9.55% and 1.73 m/s, and the average R (correlation coefficient) of them were 0.99, 0.98, 0.80 and 0.55, respectively. The average MBE of hourly 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure, 2-m relative humidity, 10-m wind speed, downward shortwave radiation and downward longwave were −0.16 °C, −6.62 hPa, −5.14%, 0.26 m/s, 33.0 W/m2 and −6.44 W/m2, the average RMSE of them were 2.62 °C, 17.10 hPa, 20.71%, 2.46 m/s, 152.9 W/m2 and 53.5 W/m2, and the average R of them were 0.96, 0.97, 0.70, 0.26, 0.91 and 0.60, respectively. Thus, the following conclusions were obtained: (1) regardless of daily or hourly validation, WRF model simulations of 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure and relative humidity are more reliable, especially for 2-m surface air temperature and surface pressure, the values of MBE were small and R were more than 0.96; (2) the WRF simulating downward shortwave radiation was relatively good, the average R between WRF simulation and hourly observation data was above 0.9, and the average R of downward longwave radiation was 0.6; (3) both wind speed and rainfall simulated from WRF model did not agree well with observation data.

Example.Answer: The use of automatic meteorological stations to collect data including air temperature, wind speed and direction, pressure, precipitation, radiation, and soil temperature and tension in the Heihe River Basin for the period between 2008 and 2009 is an example of a data collection method for high-resolution meteorological data.

Definition.Question: What does 'downscaling' mean in the context of climate data modeling?
Definition.Answer: Downscaling is a method of obtaining high-resolution climate or climate change information from relatively coarse-resolution General Circulation Models (GCMs). It involves using large scale climatic background information to establish higher resolution meteorological distribution fields by GCMs, which helps to derive high-resolution local climate information.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'forcing data' in hydrological and ecological modeling?
Definition.Answer: Forcing data refers to near-surface atmospheric elements such as air temperature, pressure, relative humidity, wind, precipitation, and radiation. These elements are used to drive hydrological, land surface, and ecological models, providing necessary input for simulations and analyses.

Comparison.Question: How do the meteorological variables measured at the automated weather station in the Linze Inland River Basin compare to those used in the validation of the WRF model using CMA and WATER project data?
Comparison.Answer: The automated weather station in the Linze Inland River Basin measures variables such as air temperature, wind speed, wind direction, pressure, precipitation, radiation, CO2 levels, and soil temperature at various depths. In comparison, the WRF model validation uses meteorological observation data that include daily and hourly data of surface temperature, pressure, relative humidity, wind speed, and radiation from CMA and WATER projects.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences between the data collection methods used in the Linze Inland River Basin automated weather station and those utilized by the CMA and WATER projects for WRF model validation?
Comparison.Answer: The Linze Inland River Basin automated weather station collects continuous data on various atmospheric and soil parameters, likely through automated sensors at specified heights and depths. In contrast, the CMA and WATER projects collect data at meteorological stations maintained by organizations, which may include manual observations alongside automated measurements, focusing on specific meteorological parameters for model validation.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the spatial and temporal resolution of the Linze Inland River Basin data differ from the downscaled data used to drive regional scale land surface models?
Comparison.Answer: The Linze Inland River Basin data provides local meteorological observations at specific heights and depths, with a high temporal resolution suited for detailed local analyses. The downscaled data used to drive regional scale land surface models, derived from GCM outputs, offers a broader spatial and temporal resolution, aiming to capture large-scale climatic patterns while addressing regional features through dynamic downscaling.

Interpretation.Question: How can downscaling techniques be used to enhance the spatial and temporal resolution of meteorological datasets for regional climate analysis?
Interpretation.Answer: Downscaling techniques, such as dynamic downscaling with regional climate models, can enhance spatial and temporal resolution by leveraging large-scale climatic data to create high-resolution meteorological distribution fields. This allows for a better representation of local features like topography, vegetation, and soil processes, which is crucial for regional-scale climate analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for high temporal-spatial resolution in forcing data for regional scale land surface models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for high temporal-spatial resolution in forcing data arises because large-scale land surface models require detailed environmental impact assessments that cannot be met by the coarse resolution of General Circulation Models (GCMs). Downscaling is necessary to provide the high-resolution data needed for regional scale or basin-scale land surface, hydrological, and ecological simulations and assimilations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the discrepancies between WRF model simulations and observed data for wind speed and rainfall?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Discrepancies between WRF model simulations and observed data for wind speed and rainfall are likely due to complexities in accurately modeling these parameters. Factors such as local topographic influences, vegetation cover, and soil hydrological processes may not be fully captured by the model, leading to variations from observed measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing downscaled GCM outputs for regional scale land surface models in terms of data accuracy and resolution?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing downscaled GCM outputs can lead to higher temporal-spatial resolution forcing data, which is crucial for regional scale or basin-scale land surface, hydrological, and ecological simulations and assimilations. This process improves the ability to capture local features characterized by topography, vegetation cover, and soil hydrological processes, making the data more reliable for regional environmental impact assessments.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of data from multiple meteorological stations and observation-strengthened sites impact the validation process of regional climate models like WRF?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating data from multiple meteorological stations and observation-strengthened sites enhances the validation process of regional climate models like WRF by providing a comprehensive dataset for comparison. This integration allows for the assessment of model accuracy across different parameters, such as surface temperature, pressure, and humidity, ultimately leading to more reliable model simulations and improved validation accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using both daily and hourly meteorological data for validating the accuracy of hydrological models in regional climate simulations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using both daily and hourly meteorological data for validation provides a more detailed temporal resolution that can highlight discrepancies in model simulations at different timescales. This comprehensive validation approach allows for a more accurate assessment of model performance, especially for parameters like surface temperature and radiation, and ensures that the hydrological models are reliably driven by the forcing data from regional climate simulations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting meteorological observation data at various temporal resolutions for regional climate modeling?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to validate the WRF model's simulation of forcing data for the Heihe River Basin by comparing it against daily and hourly meteorological observation data from multiple stations. This validation is crucial for ensuring the accuracy of forcing data before it is used to drive land surface models.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is there a need to downscale General Circulation Model outputs for regional scale land surface models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: There is a need to downscale GCM outputs because their coarse spatial and temporal resolutions are inadequate for regional scale land surface models, which require higher resolution data to accurately assess regional environmental impacts and simulate hydrological, land surface, and ecological processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in setting up and maintaining automatic meteorological stations for data collection in inland river basins?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The automatic meteorological stations in the inland river basin of Linze were installed to collect data such as atmospheric temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed, wind direction, air pressure, precipitation, net radiation, total radiation, CO2 levels, soil tension, multi-layer soil temperature, and soil heat flux. The setup involves selecting a strategic location with defined latitude, longitude, and altitude to capture comprehensive meteorological data over a specified period.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the WRF model used to downscale weather and climate data for hydrological models in the Heihe River Basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The WRF model is utilized for downscaling weather and climate data by setting up two-way nested computational domains with specific grid points and horizontal resolutions. It is initialized using real boundary conditions from NCAR-NCEP's Final Analysis data. This setup allows for deriving the necessary meteorological parameters required for hydrological models, ranging from one kilometer to thousands of kilometers in scale.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps taken to validate meteorological models using observation data from different types of stations in the Heihe River Basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The validation of meteorological models involves using daily observation data from 15 CMA stations and hourly data from seven WATER project sites. These data are compared with WRF simulations over a year to evaluate the accuracy of the forcing data. The process includes calculating metrics such as Mean Bias Error (MBE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and correlation coefficients for various parameters like surface temperature, pressure, humidity, and wind speed.

Enablement.Question: What technological and methodological advancements are necessary to enhance the temporal and spatial resolution of meteorological data collection for regional scale land surface models?
Enablement.Answer: To enhance the temporal and spatial resolution of meteorological data collection for regional scale land surface models, downscaling of General Circulation Model (GCM) output is necessary. Dynamic downscaling uses large-scale climatic background information to establish higher resolution meteorological distribution fields, often employing regional climate models which can better distinguish local features such as topography, vegetation, and soil processes.

Enablement.Question: How can the integration of meteorological observation data from multiple stations enable the validation and improvement of climate simulation models?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of meteorological observation data from multiple stations, such as those from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and the WATER project, enables the validation and improvement of climate simulation models like WRF. By comparing simulation outputs with observed data, researchers can assess the accuracy of model predictions, particularly in terms of temperature, pressure, humidity, and radiation, and make necessary adjustments for better reliability.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or data collection strategies allow for the detailed analysis of meteorological parameters required for hydrological models in complex terrains?
Enablement.Answer: In complex terrains, detailed analysis of meteorological parameters for hydrological models can be facilitated by using high-resolution regional climate models that account for local features and nonlinear interactions between large-scale and regional scales. Additionally, establishing a network of observation stations with varying altitudes and employing two-way nested computational domains can improve the granularity of data collection and parameter analysis.

Judgmental.Question: How might regional climate models be evaluated for their effectiveness in providing high-resolution forcing data in ecological and hydrological simulations?
Judgmental.Answer: Regional climate models can be evaluated for their effectiveness by comparing their simulated forcing data against observed meteorological data from multiple stations, as was done using the WRF model. The evaluation includes checking metrics like Mean Bias Error (MBE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and correlation coefficient (R) for various atmospheric elements. The reliability of the model is indicated by higher correlation coefficients and lower errors in key variables like surface temperature and pressure.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges when using downscaled General Circulation Model outputs for regional environmental impact assessments?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges include the coarse spatial and temporal resolution of the General Circulation Model outputs, which may not adequately capture regional environmental features. Downscaling processes must effectively bridge this resolution gap to account for local topography, vegetation cover, and soil hydrological processes. Ensuring the accuracy of downscaled data requires rigorous validation against regional observational datasets.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how regional climate models can provide high-resolution data without relying heavily on localized observation data.
Assertion.Answer: Regional climate models are considered effective for dynamic downscaling, using large-scale climatic background information to establish higher resolution meteorological distribution fields. They can independently distinguish local features like topography and vegetation, improving the description of local features without solely depending on observation data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how meteorological data from different stations can be effectively integrated to validate model simulations.
Assertion.Answer: Meteorological data from various stations, such as those from the China Meteorological Administration and the WATER project, can be used to validate model simulations by comparing observations with model outputs. This involves using daily and hourly data for different validation purposes to assess the model's accuracy in simulating meteorological parameters.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the effectiveness of different data collection methods used by the China Meteorological Administration and the WATER project for validating meteorological models in the Heihe River Basin.
Request/Directive.Answer: According to the metadata, the validation of meteorological models, specifically the WRF model, involved using daily meteorological observation data from CMA and hourly data from the WATER project. The effectiveness of these data collection methods was assessed by comparing model simulations with observed data. Results indicated that WRF model simulations were reliable for temperature and pressure but less so for wind speed and rainfall, suggesting that the data collection methods were more effective for certain parameters.
